content: The Act titled "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2008" includes a section on the Chesapeake Bay Crosscut Budget. The Act titled "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2008" includes a section on the Chesapeake Bay Crosscut Budget, which requires the Director to submit a financial report to Congress containing an interagency crosscut budget displaying proposed funding for Federal and State restoration activities. The Act "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2008" mandates a detailed financial report to Congress on funds received and spent by Federal and State agencies for Chesapeake Bay restoration activities in the current and preceding fiscal years. The Act "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2008" requires a detailed report to Congress on funds used for restoration activities in current and past fiscal years, as well as descriptions of proposed activities for the next fiscal year, including project details, status, funding history, and risks. The Act "Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act of 2008" mandates a report to Congress detailing restoration activities' funding, project descriptions, status, risks, coordinating entities, funding history, cost-sharing, and alignment with Chesapeake Bay Agreement goals. The report must include activities with funding amounts over $100,000 for Federal projects and over $50,000 for State projects. The Director must submit the report within 30 days of the President's annual budget submission to Congress. The financial report required by the Act must be submitted to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. This section will be effective starting from the first fiscal year after the Act's enactment when the President submits a budget to Congress. SEC. 3. ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Administrator, in consultation with other agencies, must develop an adaptive management plan for the Chesapeake Bay Program within a year of this Act. The plan includes specific objectives for improving water quality, habitat, and fisheries, stakeholder participation, monitoring, and modification of restoration activities that do not meet objectives. The Administrator is required to implement and update the adaptive management plan for the Chesapeake Bay Program every 3 years. An annual report on the plan's implementation must be submitted to Congress, detailing changes made at both programmatic and project levels through adaptive management. The effective date for paragraph (1) will be the first fiscal year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include adaptive management as a science-based process for natural resource management, the Administrator as the head of the EPA, and the Chesapeake Bay State as Maryland, West Virginia, Delaware, New York, Virginia. The term "Chesapeake Bay watershed" refers to the area where precipitation drains into the Chesapeake Bay, including 36 tributary basins in the Chesapeake Bay States. The term "chief executive" is defined as the Governor of a State or Commonwealth, or the Mayor of the District of Columbia. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. "Restoration activities" encompass Federal or State programs or projects. Activities in the Chesapeake Bay watershed include programs for protecting, conserving, and restoring resources and habitat. These activities encompass physical restoration, planning, feasibility studies, scientific research, monitoring, education, and infrastructure development.
